Comment_contributor: it appears that the prefix ni is a verbal particle ... The Prefix ni is in fact a Verbal Particle, and can be applied also to tuwale, tavelima, and saŋavul [<sanavul>, with <n> in italics].
Three is often tolu ... as in counting
four [is often] vati ... as in counting
five is not repeated on the second hand
[<m> in italics, = “nasal”]; The Prefixe tave in tavelima, five, has not been explained, but may be tavaliu, taval lima, hand on one side.
On the second hand lavea, which is prefixed to numerals, is mot reasonably taken as a word signifying the other side, or something above ... tea is a form of the numeral most commonly used for ‘one.’

in lavearua seven, laveatol eight, laveavat nine, the numerals used for two, three, and four, are evidently repeated with a difference ... It is seen at once that the true numerals two, three, four, are rua, tol, vat; which appear again in seven, eight, nine. ... The meaning of the Prefix lavea in the Numerals of the second hand has not been made out ... tea is the Numeral tea, one, obsolete in Mota, but in use elsewhere.

[<sanavul>, with <n> in italics]; but when ten, sanavul, is reached, the word is quite distinct, there is no repetition or recalling of five; and further advance is made by tens, not fives. This, then, is not purely quinary; five is used to get to ten, and then the notation becomes decimal. ... Saŋavul [<sanavul>, with <n> in italics] may be said to be naturally a Substantive.
To mark exactness of reckoning wonowono, full, is used ... full ten
[<sanavul>, with <n> in italics; <m> in italics, = “nasal”]; one ten, the unit above it one
[<m> in italics, = “nasal”]; It is not necessary always to mention the ten
[<sanavul>, with <n> in italics]; two tens
To mark exactness of reckoning wonowono, full, is used ... full twenty

Value: saŋavul tol o numei me vat
Comment_contributor: [<sanavul>, with <n> in italics; <m> in italics, = “nasal”]; The Verbal particle may equally be me, ti, ta with the numei; ... when past time is declared, ‘three tens the number-above was four.’
and so on up to ninety
[<sanavul>, with <n> in italics]
[<m> in italics, = “nasal”]; that is, a whole mele leaf.
[<m> in italics, = “nasal”]; o avaviu, from the Verb av to put one thing upon another
[<m> in italics, = “nasal”]; o avaviu, from the Verb av to put one thing upon another
[<sanavul>, with <n> in italics]; hundred once, and the pile above ten

Value: melnol vagarua o avaviu sanavul tavelima
Comment_contributor: [both <m>s in italics, = “nasal”; <sanavul>, with <n> in italics]; twice hundred, the sum-above-hundred five tens.

Substantive, Adjective, or Verb ... The exact use of tar for a thousand is settled in native usage as ten hundreds, but the word is also loosely used for any great number. There is no name for a sum greater than a thousand
one thousand
